title: Will Vladimir Putin attend the Nuclear Security Summit in Washington, DC, in March 2016?
preds: The news on NPR announced this morning that Putin will not attend this Summit.
Putin not confirmed in list https://static1.squarespace.com/static/568be36505f8e2af8023adf7/t/56fa921b20c6476d4a1f5f14/1459261981699/Heads-of-Delegation+.pdf, as expressed by Raahul_kumar
The list of peope attending the Nuclear Security Summit is up, and Putin is not on the list!
Putin likes to surprise people occasionally. But not enough time left to spring a surprise on this one.
Putin made no announcement and the month is finishing in two days.
Putin has made no announcement that he will attend this meeting, and time is running out.
Russia has publicly stated that it will not go and that it has stopped preparations for the summit. In order to keep up with its hard line, it will not want to back off on its public announcements.
Putin has made no announcement that he will attend this meeting, and time is running out.
Following the 24th March meeting with J Kerry. I would not be surprised if Putin did go. The transcript had more humour than barbs in it.
Putin has made no announcement that he will attend this meeting.

With the summit only days away, Putin is still indicating no intention to attend, with a Kremlin spokesperson indicating that there is no nuclear summit plans on Putinâ€™s official schedule. In fact, it is still reported that no one from Russia at all with attend. I think it is highly unlikely that Putin attends this event, and am therefore putting my estimate at 1%. (http://sputniknews.com/politics/20160323/1036839916/putin-nuclear-security-summit.html)
Will be excluded within The g7 states
He's reiterated that there's no way he's taking part.
He needs urgently to get in touch with other countries,intend to break the isolation and know how things are getting for Russia in the West
wants to bask in syria decision
He want to bask in Syria policy.
Updating from 5%. It's just not going to happen.
Stale forecast. Down 5% on no developments.

Putin's attendance is a low probability because:
1. Russia said they won't attend.
2. First summit was attended by Medvedev, second by Lavrov. Given the current poor bilateral US-Russia relationship, it won't be logical that Putin will attend the last one, because that will mean escalation of interest in the summit by Russia.
3. I am not giving a 0 because 'redacted' makes a good point about some unexpected, unrelated issue that would make Putin come and talk to Obama face-to-face (e.g. Syria, or some plane crash). Another reason is Putin sometimes behaves unexpectedly, e.g. recent decision to partially pull military out of Syria.

Lowering from 1% to 0%
I don't like to say there is zero percent chance of anything, but this seems reasonable here.

According to this list, Russia will not attend
http://www.nss2016.org/attending-delegations/
Former Senator Sam Nunn has traveled to Moscow to try to convince Russia to attend. Even if he succeeds, Russia will not send Pres. Putin. They would presumably send the Minister of Foreign Affairs.

Sergey Lavrov said Russia would not attend because the United States is trying to assume the role of the main and privileged player and interfere with the work of international organizations. Whatever the real reason may be, Russia was looking for an excuse not to attend.
If Russia says it won't participate in the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit, it won't. Moreover, Putin himself has never attended the NSS, there is little reason for him to start doing so now.
Coming up slightly in light of Sam Nunn's visit to Moscow.

Originally, when I made this estimate I overestimated the chances of a black swan occurring. Although, Vladimir has stated multiple times that he does not intend to attend the summit, Obama was cited saying that he would not take no for answer. (http://atimes.com/2016/02/obama-wont-take-no-for-an-answer-from-putin/) I also know how unpredictable one person’s behavior could be. For that reason, I gave a higher probability than the crowd’s average of 3%. I now want to follow Champs Know and update my opinion based on the passage of time and a changing assessment of prior information. Since time has passed and the Nuclear Summit is drawing nearer and Putin still does not plan on attending, it is less likely that he will attend. I also decided to “hunt for the right information” and search for information that contradicts my beliefs. In order to avoid confirmation basis I searched for evidence saying that Putin will attend the summit and found no reliable sources speaking out with this opinion.
Down 30% on no news from Nunn visit.
Putin has stated that he will not attend.
Russia is generally quite pro multilateralism

Up 35% on @Raisinville find regarding the Nunn visit to Russia. Two parts. (1) Could a visit be arranged. Probably if there is enough push. (2) Does it make sense for Putin? We all know the answer is "no" but it couldn't hurt to buff up his image prior to the Russian elections, especially with the frozen conflicts, Syria, weak oil prices, etc. What about a meeting with President Obama in Cuba, then moving on to DC?

US and Russia continue negotiations with Nunn's trip to Russia:
http://atimes.com/2016/02/obama-wont-take-no-for-an-answer-from-putin/
Indeed, Obama places great store on the Nuclear Security Summit on March 31-April 1. But Russia refuses to participate, accusing Washington of seeking to play first fiddle on matters of nuclear safety, which ought to be the prerogative of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna, a United Nations watchdog.
Despite putting a brave face on Moscow’s ‘Nyet’, Washington knows that the summit will be a damp squib without President Vladimir Putin’s participation. After all, Russia and the US account for 90% of world’s nuclear weapon stockpiles."

Con: Putin loves humiliating Obama, Russia did not attend the preparatory meeting, the about-face would look like demonstrating weakness for Putin
Pro: for the sake of appearances Obama would trade something real (Syria?) to Putin in exchange

I believe Putin recognizes that in order for his country to remain solvent he had to increase connectivity with his peer countries and attending the Nuclear Summit accomplished this.  Plus I believe he like many leaders realize the concept of mutually assured destruction is outdated and very dangerous.
mislim da ce dolazak putina iznenaditi sve
Russia has already declared Putin will not attend to the Summit (http://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/articles/14343/will-russia-make-nuclear-security-next-victim-of-ukraine-crisis).

Russia along with China, Pakistan, India has not signed or endorsed the Trilateral Initiative (IAEA recommendations and peer reviews).  Russia has refused to participate in the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit due to its deteriorating relationship with the United States in particular and the West in general.  This decision represents a serious blow to nuclear security since Russia has the largest stock of weapons-usable materials in the world.  Nuclear security efforts should gain wider participation, given the worldwide presence of radioactive sources, the possible use of other states’ territories in smuggling of nuclear materials and conducting terrorist attacks, and the threat of sabotage of nuclear facilities.

In 2014 Russia expressed to the United States that it will not attend the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit. Although this message was relayed quite some time ago, Putin did not see the “value” in the summit and believed that those countries who held views that differed from the organizers would be “ignored.” The Russian Foreign Ministry said it regarded the leaks about their decision at the time by the American media to be an “unsuccessful attempt to put pressure on the Russian side in order to change our position… we consider such efforts counterproductive.” Russian spokespeople have expressed their preference for the International Atomic Energy Agency for assessing global nuclear security over the Nuclear Security Summits. Mr. Putin is not one to change his mind either, further pointing to a forecast of “no.”

Wildcards, accidents, and black swans can catch you off-guard.
All the indicators are that Putin will not attend the summit.  Putin has attended any prior summit. Official news from the Ministry: Russia to take no part in Nuclear Security Summit in Washington 
It has even been publicly stated on the Russian Embassy website. 
Keeping my prediction at 1% rather than 0 because there is still a remote chance of the totally unexpected happening.
President Putin saying one thing and doing another is not unimaginable.
All the news (Foreign or Russian) indicate that Russia stopped preparing for the summit.
(no change) I'm guessing an advance team would need at least a week. Could it be kept quiet, probably not in this case.
Going to go out on a limb with "0", as we've been given no indication whatsoever to the contrary (that I am aware of).
5% for the man is known for his unpredictability.
(no change) But wonder if Putin might show up just to complain about President (Peace Prize) Obama's plans to modernize the US nuclear forces. Would get a lot of press.
Putin is too busy for this. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t-wFKNy0MZQ

Russian Foreign Ministry reiterated their 2014 position this past January, that Putin would not be attending the summit in DC in March 2016.  However, Mr Putin can obviously be unpredictable so I predict a 5% chance.

Putin has proven himself to be a politician with little to no respect for the established norms, unless those norms benefit him in some way. Maybe he'll board the wrong plane and accidentally end up in Washington, but highly doubtful. The already strenuous nature of America's relationship with Russia and Putin make this a firmly unlikely possibility.
Usually Putin sticks with his word even though it might not be the best for mother Russia
reducing due to passage of time
I am assuming that if they move the summit to Toronto and Putin attends, this will be a No, but there is as usual no way to tell from the Q, and it is folly to trust those who wrote the Q.
While Russia has officially confirmed it is not attending, Putin has made several surprises in the past, warranting a <10% chance of his attendance
They've been saying they wouldn't since 2014
Odds seem very low, but a world event between now and then could prompt his attendance.
I start my forecast as 10% because we are about one month from the summit and I see no motive to Putin to change his mind.

Welcome to Cold War 2.0
The risk of the Kremlin rolling the dice against NATO is real
02/15/16

Putin wants to be seen on the world stage as a leader of consequence. He has the war in the Middle East in his grip today . Now to make peace on his terms. There is an economic angle too in this meeting.
doubtful now with latest rhetoric from RU PM
No updates indicating a change.  Heads of state from 35 to 45 countries are expected to attend. Pakistan looks like it's going to be a hot topic.  Nothing on Russia at the moment.

The more that I think about Putin's personality and background,  I believe that he will want to exert his presence on the summit and play down the USA's influence and role in the Nuclear Security across the globe.
He will show to demonstrate Russia's power in the new world order. He won't agree to anything but will be present.
Russia is unlikely to change its decision.

Putin has attended no prior summit. Official news from the Ministry: Russia to take no part in Nuclear Security Summit in Washington
http://rbth.com/news/2016/01/13/ministry-russia-to-take-no-part-in-nuclear-security-summit-in-washington_558903
Russia to Skip Nuclear Security Summit Due to 'Unacceptable' Interference
He's a showman. Why would he pass up an opportunity for so much attention?

A Russian spokeswoman, when asked in mid-January of the country's involvement with the Nuclear Security Summit, indirectly but unmistakably said that the country would not participate. Putin will not make a surprise appearance on American soil.

The proxy war could turn more serious by then, and if not, then he'll find another excuse not to attend. Former KGB agent, too smart to risk his life in 'foreign' territory that he deems as a threat to his nation.

Initially the Russian initiative in Syria seemed to warm relationships; and the Western anger over Ukraine seemed to be fading. But the bombing of Aleppo has changed that because of the renewed pressure it's put on Turkish and European borders.

Back in 2014 Russia made the statement that it would not be attending. Since then, BBC has aired a documentary that talks about Putin's secret cache of money, Britain has said specifically that Putin was connected directly to the death of Alexander Litvenenko, and in the BBC documentary a US treasury department representative called Putin corrupt. Also Putin does not want a situation in which he is outcast like he was at the G20 summit in 2014. The visual of Putin by himself does not fit the narrative the Russian government wants to represent. The narrative they support is that the West is against Russia, but cannot deal with international issues without Russia. None of these suggest a situation in which Putin will attend the Nuclear Security Summit.
Since official announcement has been made , the chance is not significant (below 10%).
Unpredictability is one of Putin's foreign policy strategies. There is a possibility that he could he show up at the conference.
So if this conference is postponed until April, this will be a No even if he shows up for rain date, right?
It looks like it is official: Putin will not attend. Thank you, @Xu for your link: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/98916
U.S. media ire and White House posturing make this highly unlikely.
The chances are slight. They are probably slimmer after President Obama's announcement of aid to Eastern Europe.

Here is a link to one of many articles, making it clear (as Russia has for over a year now) that they will not attend.  I should have predicted on this one a long time ago.

No indication whatsoever he intends to do so.
If anybody from Russia attends the summit at all, it will most definitely not be Putin, but one of his underlings.

will send a surrogate if Russia participates.  has stated that there are no pending breakthrough decisions requiring involvement of chiefs of state.  does not want to reverse position and afford Obama/U.S. credit for something that could be deemed significant breakthrough and can achieve same outcomes without attending.

There are signs that Putin is being brought back into the fold - for instance, the lifting of sanctions on Russia in relation to Ukraine; and the fact that the USA and Russia are kind of cooperating on Syria. They are a nuclear power. They should be there, so they probably will.

All reports indicate he won't attend. As recently as last week, Russia's Foreign Ministry reps said that the Nuclear Security Summits "have played their role" and that their political agenda has been exhausted.  Unless a major development in that front happened, I don't see it changing.
Unless Putin really wants the stage for posturing or pronouncements, it is unlikely he will alter his stated course of action.
They already said they wouldn't. No visible driver to induce them to change position
Barring unforeseen events Putin will be a no show.  He is a man of his word, especially when sticking it to President Obama.
I doubt he would be welcomed, or even tolerated, at this event.
Sticking with 4%, reaffirming in the face of a surprising spike.
Putin seems to be willing to participate in international affairs
At most he'll send a lackey.
after Lord Owens report, I do not think Vlad  is coming to US

Russia repeated only a few days ago that it saw no point in the meeting and that Putin had stopped any preparations for going. So its difficult to envisage any event that could occur in the next few weeks to cause Putin to change his mind.
Overall there is no reason for him to. Furthermore, there are many reasons for him not to.

Russia said no, and has kept saying no. There's no precedent for Putin showing up, and no reason for him to show up. Since nothing new and positive has happened since my last prediction, I'm dropping my odds from 8% to 4%. (The news can always get something wrong, but I really see no positive factors leading in the direction of attendance -- I'm just leaving a few spare points around in case of randomness.)
Following others. seems like this is a done deal.
Vladimir Putin loves a stage.  The summit presents an opportunity to upstage President Obama.
Putin gets more attention by not attending. And  that creates a bigger impact in Russia.

While Putin has said he wouldn't attend, he may show up as a way to reinforce the fact that Russia is a nuclear power.  He could use the fact that "his views are being ignored" as propaganda to strengthen his political power in Russia.  I think it depends on what his next move is in the political realm, more than whether he thinks he'll be heard or not.

The Russian government has announced (in 2014 and Jan. 2016) that Putin will not attend the next NSS. While I do not have time to do research on the number of times in "recent" history a government has announced the leader would NOT attend a major international meeting, and then changed its mind and attended, I would venture to guess that it is not very often. Adding in the current coolness of the US-Russia relationship, I think it is even less likely that Putin would change his mind and decide to attend.

Putin is right, his views will be ignored because that is the current political correct thing to do in Washington. No matter how right he is anybody in Washington who does not want to lose his job will ignore him.
Jan 13 statement from Russia confirms they do not plan on attending
Russia had let the US know that it would not attend the 2016 summit back in 2014.
Downgrading as a result of looking at @GJDrew's links, and Putin's lack of any announcement about attending the event. I doubt if he'll show up as a surprise.

From Interfax January 13, 2016 - Nuclear Security Summits "have played their role" and their political agenda has been exhausted; Russia has stopped preparing for the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit in Washington DC, Russian Foreign Ministry spokesperson Maria Zakharova said.

“While preparing for the 2016 summit, its organizers have changed the core conception of the event by suggesting to develop some sort of ‘punishment’ for the International Atomic Energy Agency, the Global Initiative to Combat Nuclear Terrorism, as well as for the UN, Interpol, and the Global Partnership.”
“Obviously these recommendations, whatever formal status they may have, will become an attempt to attach the opinion of a limited group of states to the aforementioned international organizations and initiatives by circumventing their own mechanisms of making political decisions,” Zakharova added.
According to Zakharova, Moscow believes “the creation of such a precedent of outside meddling in the work plan of international organizations that have great expert potential and embedded in democratic procedures to be unacceptable.
In November 2014, the Russian Foreign Ministry confirmed that Russia would not be attending the event, saying it would rather focus on the IAEA High Level Conference on Nuclear Security to be held this year.
“This is why Russian President Vladimir Putin, as you know, has decided to drop our participation in the preparations for the 2016 summit,” Zakharova said.
“We understand that the IAEA with all of its necessary expert potential should play the central role in coordinating community efforts in nuclear security,” she added."

There is no reason why Russia will change their mind and attend this conference they are much more likely to have influence at the IAEA

- Putin himself has never attended the NSS and Russia has announced it will not attend the NSS 2016, though the announcement were made a year ago. 
- The US expressed interest in Russian participation in March 2015, but the tension with Russia has been a sabotage, especially over the Ukraine issue, which was made visible since a lower ranking official had attended the 2014 which took place around the same time as the Crimea annexation 
- Putin has claimed to have escalated Russia's nuclear capability in Nov 2015, indicating the US and its allies to pay attention back to Russia as it is still capable of nuclear powers, which may prompt the US to urge Russia more to join the NSS 2016, though whether Putin himself will take place is another consideration ( I am raising the odds quite a bit for this from the initial 1% chance)
- Putin labels the US a security threat to Russia for the first time, combining with his declination statement in 2014, I am erring my forecast back to the low side.

Putin will use any forum to publicize his views and pursue his goals.  The risk is that a boycott could also be politically effective.  Trumps fondness for him and the reverse during primaries could affect what he does,  in either direction.

In order to forecast this question, I asked and attempted to answer the following sub questions:
US and Russian relations will probably improve slightly in 2016

Putin will attend. 
1. Russia Turkey relations will have collapsed to the point where Putin will be in position make his next moves - positioning troops. He will use the summit as an opportunity to showcase his power back home to keep the nation behind him as the economy struggles due to the resulting sanctions and troop deployments.
2. Putin will use the summit to extract concessions from the U.S. and NATO on easing opposition to his Ukraine policy. He will use the press to showcase his actions in Syria and to send strong messages to Syrian rebels warning them to cease fighting. He will make very clear that the U.S. is to stay out of his way in Syria. In private consultations with President Obama, which will leak later, he will warn the U.S. to stay out of his way in Turkey and Syria.

Started with a baseline of 0%, since Putin himself has never attended the Nuclear Security Summit. Added 10% because of poll that 75% of Russians want improved relations with the US (http://www.economist.com/news/europe/21679701-popular-president-muffles-his-anti-western-rhetoric-russias-economy-shrinks-vladimir-putin?zid=307&ah=5e80419d1bc9821ebe173f4f0f060a07) (10%). I added 2% because the article also says there was almost no Anti-Americanism in Putin's recent speech (12%). I added 1% because of this March article about US still talking with Russia about the summit (http://sputniknews.com/us/20150331/1020230493.html) (13%). I subtracted 5% because Russia said they would skip the summit (8%). I subtracted 5% because Putin's approval rating is still high so he can do what he wants (3%). I subtracted 2% because of what everyone else is saying and because of my own gut feeling (1%).

He did say that he does not consider America an enemy. 
The story wouldn't be 'Russia Backpedaling.' It'll be 'Putin comes to summit just to meet with Trump.'

I don't see what Putin has to gained to go back on his word.  Attending may look like he's caving and it's not something I think he wants to show to an new incoming president.
The will issue over Syria that make Russia not attend
Putin is attempting to build his reputation as a statesman. this is just another platform for him to give a speech.

Putin wants a bit more give and take from the West but he is not getting it. If the US really wants him to attend they will have to make some concession in another area or areas apart from Nuclear issues that will be important to Russia.  Maybe  a formal coalition on Middle East peace keeping / enforcement ? Ukraine and the Crimea although in the background will not go away and there's must be some real and lasting agreement between Russia and the West on the way forward. Putin will only attend if he is treated in accordance with his status as a "Nuclear Superpower".

The chances are very small, that Russia will attend and therefore VP will not attend. They are said to believe that the views of states which disagreed with the event's organizers would be ignored.   It seems that Russia prefers the IAEA summit held in the same year.

- Putin himself has never attended the NSS and Russia has announced it will not attend the NSS 2016, though the announcement were made a year ago.

Russia has informed Washington that it will not attend the summit. Russia objects to the notion that the US should assume the lead role in global nuclear security.  At this point, Russian attendance would require a substantial U-turn in policy. Even if such a reversal of this decision might happen, the personal attendance of Mr Putin would still be uncertain. Russia is rather seeking to impact nuclear security through the existing structures of the IAEA (Internatioanl Atomic Energy Agency). Given that this appears to be an issue of international institutional arrangements for Russia, the probability of Russian attendance is low and there is an even lower chance that Mr Putin would give the event added credibility and kudos with his personal attendance.

I'm not going to change my forecast yet, but I'm wondering if I may be viewing this Question through too narrow of a lens. Like the business executive who seeks to co-ordinate business trips with personal activities (Florida in the winter) so as to accrue the intangible benefit (of sunshine) under a business expense reimbursement scheme, is it possible that Putin has demonstrated any historical proclivity to "kill two birds with one stone" by making trips which, on the surface appear to be for reason X, but behind-the-scenes may equally be for reason Y? I ask this because the S-300 delivery was apparently consummated under the auspices of Putin attending a regional gas conference. Might it be possible that Putin might wish to visit the United States at this time for some reason independent of the Nuclear Security Summit, and the Summit might be a useful cover for such a visit? Kerry will supposedly be in Moscow this week. There are, one would expect, continuous discussions between Washington and Moscow on a variety of subjects at a variety of levels. Perhaps there is some subject that percolates to the top, so to speak, where a face-to-face meeting between Putin and Obama would be important. Certainly such a meeting could occur independently of the Summit, but then the subject of the meeting becomes a special topic of (perhaps undesired) focus. To my mind Russia has more-or-less divorced themselves from the U.S.-led  Summit approach to nuclear security, and seems to be in favor of establishing the IAEA as the premier international body for this function. Why would they desire to support the "Summit alternative" to the IAEA? Yet, such a meeting would provide a very plausible reason for Putin to come to the United States without an alternative reason becoming the focus of public attention. Are there any alternative reasons that might spring to mind?

(Source: http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/islamic-state/11918489/What-could-Isil-actually-do-if-they-got-their-hands-on-nuclear-material.html)  So, why should Putin attend the meeting?  Kiss and hugs with the Western, maybe.
The Paris attacks will force the US and Russia to cooperate to prevent a nuclear incident.  He will attend also because it will enhance his position at home

Putin hasn't attended a summit yet, opting to send his minister of foreign affairs last time. He's also said that Russia won't attend this year because they aren't happy the U.S. Is hosting it and trying to assert itself as the leader.  I would go lower, but tensions in Syria may cause him to rethink.
Higher than otherwise based on current terrorism situation
Putin wants a higher profile for himself and Russia.
Hard to see this occurring in quasi- normal situation. The Mid-East chaos and spillover effects could incentivize Putin's participation.
would normally say zero but given fluidity of current relations anything is possible in the next six months
This prediction may increase odds over the next 45 days depending upon how needful Putin is to assure long term stability.

I'm not seeing him personally attend. There is no advantage for his presence in the U.S. at this time, and nothing to gain with this visit. Although somewhat softened recently, his tough persona plays well to his base in Russia. A visit to the U.S. would diminish that image.

The recent forced thawing of icy relations between the USA and Russia in light of the the Paris attacks appears to provide further grounds why Vladmir Putin should keep the Americans as partners for now. The haziness surrounding the recent unexplained crash of the Russian aircraft over Sharm el Sheik, Egypt put Putin in hawkish mode. As a former intelligence chief, he can not afford not to be there. He surely will attend. If not, the Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov, a trusted Lieutenant will definitely attend in place of the Russian President.
Base rate: 1) Past Russian attendance in NSS and 2) rate of guestimated frequency of Russian absence from / refusal to attend various conferences.
Putin will not want to agree to any conditions
NE POZNAJETE VLADIMIRA PUTINA ZATO DAJETE MALE PROGNOZE
I'm new to this game, but reading the previous forecasters I found the arguments of myfuamerica and the person who provided the Russian media view the most compelling.

Putin has switched to grownup mode for a while, and Washington and Moscow are currently pretending to care about each other on account of the ISIL situation.  Some chance he'll send the PM of the Week instead, though.
The fight against ISIS has brought USA & Russia closer together.

I don't see any reason Vladimir Putin would personally attend this event.  He hasn't visited the United States (Trips to UN excluded), since 2007.   I would say there is a  30% chance Russia will end up sending a representative, but almost no chance of Vladimir Putin himself attending.

Probably not. He was just recently in US at the UN. The rejection of the visas to the Russian delegates of the international assembly of parliamentarians along with the general assembly of the UN at it's 70th anniversary was an unfriendly move by the Obama administration. 
It may actually lead to a relocation of such events in the future, since US broke its obligations in this regards to grant access to all attendees.
Russia is moving fast to regain its appropriate weight within the international community. Many heads of states are visiting it now for consultations and there for there is less motivation for the Russian President to travel abroad in such short term.
The announcement of non-participation in 2014 was only made to increase leverage in Iranian nuclear deal.
The recent ISIS incidents would suggest that there is some room for cooperation at least with respect to suppressing ISIS. So perhaps he will attend to encourage this cooperation.
There is  a remote possibility that Mr Putin will change his stance under the current circumstances. The summit will have looked at as an opportunity for Russia to reveal more of its "SYRIAN CARDS"

The situation in the middle east is changing rapidly as the US and Europe pivot into a more active role in Syria, Russia is critical to that process and Putin wants a seat  at the global table, albeit on his terms, seems as if that has become more likely, increasing the probability of him engaging.

I think its too early to tell. While Russia may not be particularly interested, it would not bode well for them to appear uncooperative in the Summit process, especially considering their growing nuclear energy exports. Unless there is value from shunning it, I think he might attend.
This issue is not crucial to Russian interests, and would only be used for domestic purposes by US interests. So it is not the issue that would bring Putin to USA.
Balance of power is moving towards Russia already and so not in his interest to go - especally not to the US
Lavrov attended in 2014. There is really no point for Putin to come to the USA on such superficial premises.
Forecasting downward. Since I don't think it will happen, I'll bring my percentage down to be more in line with other skeptics.
While Putin is not adverse to publicity, he may accurately feel that sharing the lime lights with "Liveshot  John" and "loquacious Barry" is time not well spent.

Interesting question that could break either way. Putin may want to have a seat at the table now that he's become somewhat respectable again, on the other hand, he may feel confident in blowing it off for the same reason, and to show that Washington is no longer the ringmaster. I think he'll stay away; attending would enhance U.S. prestige, especially since Putin previously said he would not be attending.

Russian official motives are a bit more clearly elaborated here:
http://orientalreview.org/2014/11/21/why-is-russia-going-to-skip-the-nuclear-security-summit-in-the-us/
Short version:
	1. from a practical point of view, the goals set by the summitsâ€™ political agenda have been accomplished;
	2. summit hosts (US, SK, Netherlands) have (had) too much power over final documents;
	3. preparation of guiding documents by limited-member groups, for organizations such as IAEA, UN, Interpol, etc., is unacceptable for Russia
Last, but not least, privileged role of US is not tolerated.
Putin likes being on the big stage. He will attend, unless events outside his control force his hand.
failure to attend brings the most future benefit
Attending might chance highlighting some of the Russian nuclear force updates which perhaps would undercut Putin's ability to manage the message internally.
Chance he'll warm up over ISIS situation.
